items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1pm and 3pm today, Monday 26 December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.95 mAODN at 1:45pm today which is 0.62m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, Monday 26 December.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:45pm and 2:45pm today, Monday 26 December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.7 mAODN at 1:45pm today which is 0.54m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today, Monday 26 December.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1pm and 3pm today, Monday 26 December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high at Battlesbridge, and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.95mAODN at 1:45pm today, which is 0.62m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:45pm and 2:45pm today, Monday 26 December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.7 mAODN at 1:45pm today which is 0.54m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message:
Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.
Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Light rainfall is forecast for tomorrow, 27/12/2022, though no flooding impacts are expected.   
We continue to monitor the situation.

There is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow's high tides. However, we will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  
Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
We expect flood levels to remain high until after the high tide tonight, 26/12/2022.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen following recent rainfall. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
Some further rain is forecast on Wednesday 28 December however we do not currently expect any further impacts on river levels. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 
Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but steady on the Lower Cherwell as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today, 26/12/2022, especially in the areas around Thrupp. 
Today is forecast to be mainly dry, with further rainfall showers expected tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 26/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall. This alert has been issued due to elevated river levels around Sandford. This message will not be updated, but river levels may rise further and come out of banks. Please take care when walking along the Thames Path and check River Levels online for current levels at Kings Lock, Godstow Lock, Osney Lock, Iffly Lock, Minns Estate and Cold Harbour.
 
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:15pm and 3:15pm this afternoon, Monday 26 December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.68mAODN at 2:15pm, on Monday 26 December, 0.6m above tide tables, wind Force 4, south-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today.

items.description: The Essex coast from Fobbing to Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:15pm and 3:15pm this afternoon, Monday 26 December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are within low lying land around Corringham, Tilbury, Grays, Thurrock and Purfleet. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.68 mAODN at 2:15pm, on Monday 26 December, which is 0.6m above tide tables, wind Force 4, south-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Monday 26 December.
